context: Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.
question: Which one of the following could be the schedule of the students' reports?
options: A) Mon. morning: Helen; Mon. afternoon: Robert Tues. morning: Olivia; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Lenore; Wed. afternoon: Kyle
B) Mon. morning: Irving; Mon. afternoon: Olivia Tues. morning: Helen; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Nina; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
C) Mon. morning: Lenore; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: George; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Robert; Wed. afternoon: Irving
D) Mon. morning: Nina; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: Robert; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Olivia; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
E) Mon. morning: Olivia; Mon. afternoon: Nina Tues. morning: Irving; Tues. afternoon: Helen Wed. morning: Kyle; Wed. afternoon: George
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
students = EnumSort([George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, Robert])
reports = EnumSort([Mon_morning, Mon_afternoon, Tues_morning, Tues_afternoon, Wed_morning, Wed_afternoon])
gives = Function([students, reports] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([s:students], Count([r:reports], gives(s, r)) == 1) ::: exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon
And(gives(George, Tues_morning), Not(gives(George, Mon_morning)), Not(gives(George, Tues_afternoon)), Not(gives(George, Wed_morning)), Not(gives(George, Wed_afternoon))) ::: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report
And(Not(gives(Olivia, Tues_afternoon)), Not(gives(Robert, Tues_afternoon))) ::: Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report
And(gives(Nina, Tues_morning), gives(Helen, Wed_morning), gives(Irving, Wed_morning), Not(gives(Nina, Wed_morning))) ::: If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following could be the schedule of the students' reports?
is_sat(And(gives(Helen, Mon_morning), gives(Robert, Mon_afternoon), gives(Olivia, Tues_morning), gives(Irving, Tues_afternoon), gives(Lenore, Wed_morning), gives(Kyle, Wed_afternoon))) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(gives(Irving, Mon_morning), gives(Olivia, Mon_afternoon), gives(Helen, Tues_morning), gives(Kyle, Tues_afternoon), gives(Nina, Wed_morning), gives(Lenore, Wed_afternoon))) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(gives(Lenore, Mon_morning), gives(Helen, Mon_afternoon), gives(George, Tues_morning), gives(Kyle, Tues_afternoon), gives(Robert, Wed_morning), gives(Irving, Wed_afternoon))) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(gives(Nina, Mon_morning), gives(Helen, Mon_afternoon), gives(Robert, Tues_morning), gives(Irving, Tues_afternoon), gives(Olivia, Wed_morning), gives(Lenore, Wed_afternoon))) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(gives(Olivia, Mon_morning), gives(Nina, Mon_afternoon), gives(Irving, Tues_morning), gives(Helen, Tues_afternoon), gives(Kyle, Wed_morning), gives(George, Wed_afternoon))) ::: (E)
------

context: A panel of five scientists will be formed. The panelists will be selected from among three botanists—F, G, and H—three chemists—K, L, and M—and three zoologists—P, Q, and R. Selection is governed by the following conditions: The panel must include at least one scientist of each of the three types. If more than one botanist is selected, then at most one zoologist is selected. F and K cannot both be selected. K and M cannot both be selected. If M is selected, both P and R must be selected.
question: Which one of the following is an acceptable selection of scientists for the panel?
options: A) F, G, K, P, Q
B) G, H, K, L, M
C) G, H, K, L, R
D) H, K, M, P, R
E) H, L, M, P, Q
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
scientists = EnumSort([F, G, H, K, L, M, P, Q, R])
selected = Function([scientists] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([s:scientists], And(selected(s), Not(selected(s)))) ::: The panel must include at least one scientist of each of the three types
And(selected(F), selected(G), selected(H)) ::: If more than one botanist is selected, then at most one zoologist is selected
And(selected(F), selected(K)) ::: F and K cannot both be selected
And(selected(K), selected(M)) ::: K and M cannot both be selected
And(selected(M), selected(P), selected(R)) ::: If M is selected, both P and R must be selected

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following is an acceptable selection of scientists for the panel?
is_valid(And(selected(F), selected(G), selected(K), selected(P), selected(Q))) ::: (A)
is_valid(And(selected(G), selected(H), selected(K), selected(L), selected(M))) ::: (B)
is_valid(And(selected(G), selected(H), selected(K), selected(L), selected(R))) ::: (C)
is_valid(And(selected(H), selected(K), selected(M), selected(P), selected(R))) ::: (D)
is_valid(And(selected(H), selected(L), selected(M), selected(P), selected(Q))) ::: (E)
------

A group of five people—A, B, C, D, and E—will be formed. The group must include at least one person of each of the following three types: a musician, a painter, and a sculptor. The following conditions apply: If a musician is selected, then a painter is also selected. If a painter is selected, then a sculptor is also selected. If a sculptor is selected, then a musician is also selected.

context: A loading dock consists of exactly six bays numbered 1 through 6 consecutively from one side of the dock to the other. Each bay is holding a different one of exactly six types of cargo—fuel, grain, livestock, machinery, produce, or textiles. The following apply: The bay holding grain has a higher number than the bay holding livestock. The bay holding livestock has a higher number than the bay holding textiles. The bay holding produce has a higher number than the bay holding fuel. The bay holding textiles is next to the bay holding produce.
question: Which one of the following must be false?
options: A) The bay holding fuel is next to the bay holding machinery.
B) The bay holding grain is next to the bay holding machinery.
C) The bay holding livestock is next to the bay holding fuel.
D) The bay holding produce is next to the bay holding livestock.
E) The bay holding textiles is next to the bay holding fuel.
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
bays = EnumSort([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])
cargos = EnumSort([fuel, grain, livestock, machinery, produce, textiles])
holds = Function([bays, cargos] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([b:bays], Count([c:cargos], holds(b, c)) == 1) ::: each bay is holding a different one of exactly six types of cargo
And(holds(2, livestock), holds(3, grain)) ::: The bay holding grain has a higher number than the bay holding livestock
And(holds(3, livestock), holds(4, textiles)) ::: The bay holding livestock has a higher number than the bay holding textiles
And(holds(4, produce), holds(5, fuel)) ::: The bay holding produce has a higher number than the bay holding fuel
And(holds(5, textiles), holds(6, produce)) ::: The bay holding textiles is next to the bay holding produce

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following must be false?
is_false(holds(1, machinery)) ::: (A)
is_false(holds(2, machinery)) ::: (B)
is_false(holds(3, machinery)) ::: (C)
is_false(holds(4, machinery)) ::: (D)
is_false(holds(5, machinery)) ::: (E)
------

context: An administrator must assign parking spaces to six new employees: Robertson, Souza, Togowa, Vaughn, Xu, and Young. Each of the six employees must be assigned one of the following parking spaces: #1, #2, #3, #4, #5, or #6. No two employees can be assigned the same parking space. The following rules govern the assignment of parking spaces: Young must be assigned a higher-numbered parking space than Togowa. Xu must be assigned a higher-numbered parking space than Souza. Robertson must be assigned a higher-numbered parking space than Young. Robertson must be assigned parking space #1, #2, #3, or #4.
question: If Togowa is assigned a higher-numbered parking space than Souza, then which one of the following could be true?
options: A) Young is assigned parking space #2.
B) Vaughn is assigned parking space #5.
C) Togowa is assigned parking space #3.
D) Souza is assigned parking space #2.
E) Robertson is assigned parking space #3.
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
employees = EnumSort([Robertson, Souza, Togowa, Vaughn, Xu, Young])
parking_spaces = EnumSort([1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6])
assigns = Function([employees, parking_spaces] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([e:employees], And(assigns(e, 1), assigns(e, 2), assigns(e, 3), assigns(e, 4))) ::: Robertson must be assigned parking space #1, #2, #3, or #4
ForAll([e:employees], And(assigns(e, 1), assigns(e, 2), assigns(e, 3), assigns(e, 4), assigns(e, 5), assigns(e, 6))) ::: each of the six employees must be assigned one of the following parking spaces: #1, #2, #3, #4, #5, or #6
ForAll([e:employees], Not(And(assigns(e, 1), assigns(e, 2), assigns(e, 3), assigns(e, 4), assigns(e, 5), assigns(e, 6)))) ::: no two employees can be assigned the same parking space
And(assigns(Togowa, 1), assigns(Togowa, 2), assigns(Togowa, 3), assigns(Togowa, 4), assigns(Togowa, 5), assigns(Togowa, 6)) ::: Young must be assigned a higher-numbered parking space than Togowa
And(assigns(Xu, 1), assigns(Xu, 2), assigns(Xu, 3), assigns(Xu, 4), assigns(Xu, 5), assigns(Xu, 6)) ::: Xu must be assigned a higher-numbered parking space than Souza
And(assigns(Robertson, 1), assigns(Robertson, 2), assigns(Robertson, 3), assigns(Robertson, 4), assigns(Robertson, 5), assigns(Robertson, 6)) ::: Robertson must be assigned a higher-numbered parking space than Young

# Options
Question ::: If Togowa is assigned a higher-numbered parking space than Souza, then which one of the following could be true?
is_sat(And(assigns(Togowa, 2), assigns(Young, 3))) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(assigns(Vaughn, 5), assigns(Souza, 2))) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(assigns(Togowa, 3), assigns(Souza, 2))) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(assigns(Souza, 2), assigns(Young, 3))) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(assigns(Robertson, 3), assigns(Young, 2))) ::: (E)
------

context: A government needs to assign new ambassadors to Venezuela, Yemen, and Zambia. The candidates for these ambassadorships are Jaramillo, Kayne, Landon, Novetzke, and Ong. One ambassador will be assigned to each country, and no ambassador will be assigned to more than one country. The assignment of the ambassadors must meet the following constraints: Either Kayne or Novetzke, but not both, is assigned to one of the ambassadorships. If Jaramillo is assigned to one of the ambassadorships, then so is Kayne. If Ong is assigned as ambassador to Venezuela, Kayne is not assigned as ambassador to Yemen. If Landon is assigned to an ambassadorship, it is to Zambia.
question: Which one of the following could be the assignment of the ambassadors?
options: A) Venezuela: Jaramillo Yemen: Ong Zambia: Novetzke
B) Venezuela: Kayne Yemen: Jaramillo Zambia: Landon
C) Venezuela: Landon Yemen: Novetzke Zambia: Ong
D) Venezuela: Novetzke Yemen: Jaramillo Zambia: Kayne
E) Venezuela: Ong Yemen: Kayne Zambia: Landon
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
ambassadors = EnumSort([Jaramillo, Kayne, Landon, Novetzke, Ong])
countries = EnumSort([Venezuela, Yemen, Zambia])
assigns = Function([ambassadors, countries] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([a:ambassadors], And(assigns(a, Venezuela), assigns(a, Yemen), assigns(a, Zambia))) ::: one ambassador will be assigned to each country, and no ambassador will be assigned to more than one country
ForAll([a:ambassadors], And(assigns(a, Venezuela), assigns(a, Yemen))) ::: Either Kayne or Novetzke, but not both, is assigned to one of the ambassadorships
ForAll([a:ambassadors], And(assigns(a, Venezuela), assigns(a, Yemen), assigns(a, Zambia))) ::: If Jaramillo is assigned to one of the ambassadorships, then so is Kayne
ForAll([a:ambassadors], And(assigns(a, Venezuela), assigns(a, Yemen), assigns(a, Zambia))) ::: If Ong is assigned as ambassador to Venezuela, Kayne is not assigned as ambassador to Yemen
ForAll([a:ambassadors], And(assigns(a, Venezuela), assigns(a, Yemen), assigns(a, Zambia))) ::: If Landon is assigned to an ambassadorship, it is to Zambia

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following could be the assignment of the ambassadors?
is_sat(And(assigns(Jaramillo, Venezuela), assigns(Kayne, Yemen), assigns(Novetzke, Zambia))) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(assigns(Kayne, Venezuela), assigns(Jaramillo, Yemen), assigns(Landon, Zambia))) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(assigns(Landon, Venezuela), assigns(Novetzke, Yemen), assigns(Ong, Zambia))) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(assigns(Novetzke, Venezuela), assigns(Jaramillo, Yemen), assigns(Kayne, Zambia))) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(assigns(Ong, Venezuela), assigns(Kayne, Yemen), assigns(Landon, Zambia))) ::: (E)
------

If Landon is assigned to an ambassadorship, it is to Zambia.
question: The pair of candidates who are not assigned to ambassadorships could be
options: A) Jaramillo and Novetzke

raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
ambassadors = EnumSort([Venezuela, Yemen, Zambia])
candidates = EnumSort([Jaramillo, Kayne, Landon, Novetzke, Ong])
assigns = Function([candidates, ambassadors] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([a:ambassadors], Count([c:candidates], assigns(c, a)) <= 1) ::: one ambassador will be assigned to each country, and no ambassador will be assigned to more than one country
And(assigns(Kayne, Venezuela), assigns(Novetzke, Venezuela)) ::: Either Kayne or Novetzke, but not both, is assigned to one of the ambassadorships
And(assigns(Jaramillo, Venezuela), assigns(Kayne, Yemen)) ::: If Jaramillo is assigned to one of the ambassadorships, then so is Kayne
And(assigns(Ong, Venezuela), Not(assigns(Kayne, Yemen))) ::: If Ong is assigned as ambassador to Venezuela, Kayne is not assigned as ambassador to Yemen
assigns(Landon, Zambia) ::: If Landon is assigned to an ambassadorship, it is to Zambia

# Options
Question ::: The pair of candidates who are not assigned to ambassadorships could be
is_sat(And(Not(assigns(Jaramillo, Venezuela)), Not(assigns(Novetzke, Venezuela)))) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(Not(assigns(Jaramillo, Venezuela)), Not(assigns(Ong, Venezuela)))) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(Not(assigns(Kayne, Yemen)), Not(assigns(Landon, Zambia)))) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(Not(assigns(Kayne, Yemen)), Not(assigns(Novetzke, Yemen)))) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(Not(assigns(Landon, Zambia)), Not(assigns(Ong, Venezuela)))) ::: (E)

context: On the first day of a two-day study for a cycling magazine, four riders—Reynaldo, Seamus, Theresa, and Yuki—will each test one of four bicycles—F, G, H, and J. Each rider will then test a different one of the bicycles on the second day. Each rider tests only one bicycle per day, and all four bicycles are tested each day. The assignment of riders to bicycles is subject to the following conditions: Reynaldo cannot test F. Yuki cannot test J. Theresa must be one of the testers for H. The bicycle that Yuki tests on the first day must be tested by Seamus on the second day.
question: If Theresa tests G on the second day, then which one of the following must be true?
options: A) Reynaldo tests H on the first day.
B) Reynaldo tests J on the first day.
C) Theresa tests H on the second day.
D) Theresa tests J on the first day.
E) Yuki tests H on the second day.
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
riders = EnumSort([Reynaldo, Seamus, Theresa, Yuki])
bicycles = EnumSort([F, G, H, J])
tests = Function([riders, bicycles] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([r:riders], And(tests(r, F), Not(tests(r, G)))) ::: Reynaldo cannot test F
ForAll([r:riders], And(tests(r, J), Not(tests(r, H)))) ::: Yuki cannot test J
ForAll([r:riders], And(tests(r, H), Not(tests(r, J)))) ::: Theresa must be one of the testers for H
ForAll([r:riders], And(tests(r, F), tests(r, G))) ::: The bicycle that Yuki tests on the first day must be tested by Seamus on the second day

# Options
Question ::: If Theresa tests G on the second day, then which one of the following must be true?
is_sat(And(tests(Theresa, G), tests(Reynaldo, H))) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(tests(Theresa, G), tests(Reynaldo, J))) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(tests(Theresa, G), tests(Theresa, H))) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(tests(Theresa, G), tests(Theresa, J))) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(tests(Theresa, G), tests(Yuki, H))) ::: (E)
------

context: A chemistry class has six lab sessions scheduled over three days—Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday—one session heing held each morning and one each afternoon. Each session will be led by a different lab assistant—Julio, Kevin, Lan, Nessa, Olivia, or Rebecca. The assignment of lab assistants to sessions is constrained as follows: Kevin and Rebecca must lead sessions that meet on the same day. Lan and Olivia cannot lead sessions that meet on the same day. Nessa must lead an afternoon session. Julio's session must meet on an earlier day of the week than Olivia's.
question: If Julio leads the Thursday afternoon session, then for how many of the other lab assistants can one determine which sessions they lead?
options: A) one
B) two
C) three
D) four
E) five
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
days = EnumSort([Wednesday, Thursday, Friday])
sessions = EnumSort([morning, afternoon])
assistants = EnumSort([Julio, Kevin, Lan, Nessa, Olivia, Rebecca])
leads = Function([assistants, days, sessions] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([a:assistants], Count([d:days, s:sessions], leads(a, d, s)) == 1) ::: each assistant leads exactly one session
And(leads(Kevin, Thursday, morning), leads(Rebecca, Thursday, afternoon)) ::: Kevin and Rebecca must lead sessions that meet on the same day
And(Not(leads(Lan, Thursday, morning)), Not(leads(Olivia, Thursday, morning))) ::: Lan and Olivia cannot lead sessions that meet on the same day
leads(Nessa, Friday, afternoon) ::: Nessa must lead an afternoon session
leads(Julio, Wednesday, afternoon) ::: Julio's session must meet on an earlier day of the week than Olivia's

# Options
Question ::: If Julio leads the Thursday afternoon session, then for how many of the other lab assistants can one determine which sessions they lead?
is_sat(And(leads(Julio, Thursday, afternoon), Count([a:assistants], And(a!= Julio, leads(a, Thursday, afternoon))) == 1)) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(leads(Julio, Thursday, afternoon), Count([a:assistants], And(a!= Julio, leads(a, Thursday, morning))) == 1)) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(leads(Julio, Thursday, afternoon), Count([a:assistants], And(a!= Julio, leads(a, Wednesday, afternoon))) == 1)) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(leads(Julio, Thursday, afternoon), Count([a:assistants], And(a!= Julio, leads(a, Wednesday, morning))) == 1)) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(leads(Julio, Thursday, afternoon), Count([a:assistants], And(a!= Julio, leads(a, Friday, afternoon))) == 1)) ::: (E)
------

context: A shopping center has exactly seven spaces—space 1 through space 7—arranged in a straight row. Seven businesses—an optometrist, a pharmacy, two restaurants, a shoe store, a toy store, and a veterinarian—will be located in the shopping center, one in each space. The locations of the businesses are subject to the following constraints: The pharmacy must be at one end of the row and one of the restaurants at the other. The two restaurants must be separated by at least two other businesses. The pharmacy must be next to either the optometrist or the veterinarian. The toy store cannot be next to the veterinarian.
question: Which one of the following could be the order of the businesses in spaces 1 through 7 respectively?
options: A) pharmacy, optometrist, shoe store, restaurant, veterinarian, toy store, restaurant
B) pharmacy, veterinarian, optometrist, shoe store, restaurant, toy store, restaurant
C) restaurant, shoe store, veterinarian, pharmacy, optometrist, toy store, restaurant
D) restaurant, toy store, optometrist, restaurant, veterinarian, shoe store, pharmacy
E) restaurant, optometrist, toy store, restaurant, shoe store, veterinarian, pharmacy
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
spaces = EnumSort([space_1, space_2, space_3, space_4, space_5, space_6, space_7])
businesses = EnumSort([optometrist, pharmacy, restaurant_1, restaurant_2, shoe_store, toy_store, veterinarian])
located = Function([businesses, spaces] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([b:businesses], Count([s:spaces], located(b, s)) == 1) ::: each business is located in exactly one space
And(located(pharmacy, space_1), located(restaurant_1, space_7)) ::: The pharmacy must be at one end of the row and one of the restaurants at the other
And(located(restaurant_1, space_1), located(restaurant_2, space_7)) ::: The two restaurants must be separated by at least two other businesses
And(located(pharmacy, space_1), Or(located(optometrist, space_2), located(veterinarian, space_2))) ::: The pharmacy must be next to either the optometrist or the veterinarian
And(located(veterinarian, space_1), Not(located(toy_store, space_2))) ::: The toy store cannot be next to the veterinarian

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following could be the order of the businesses in spaces 1 through 7 respectively?
is_valid(And(located(pharmacy, space_1), located(optometrist, space_2), located(shoe_store, space_3), located(restaurant_1, space_4), located(veterinarian, space_5), located(toy_store, space_6), located(restaurant_2, space_7))) ::: (A)
is_valid(And(located(pharmacy, space_1), located(veterinarian, space_2), located(optometrist, space_3), located(shoe_store, space_4), located(restaurant_1, space_5), located(toy_store, space_6), located(restaurant_2, space_7))) ::: (B)
is_valid(And(located(restaurant_1, space_1), located(shoe_store, space_2), located(veterinarian, space_3), located(pharmacy, space_4), located(optometrist, space_5), located(toy_store, space_6), located(restaurant_2, space_7))) ::: (C)
is_valid(And(located(restaurant_1, space_1), located(toy_store, space_2), located(optometrist, space_3), located(restaurant_2, space_4), located(veterinarian, space_5), located(shoe_store, space_6), located(pharmacy, space_7))) ::: (D)
is_valid(And(located(restaurant_1, space_1), located(optometrist, space_2), located(toy_store, space_3), located(restaurant_2, space_4), located(shoe_store, space_5), located(veterinarian, space_6), located(pharmacy, space_7))) ::: (E)
------

context: A software company employs exactly seven sales representatives—Kim, Mahr, Parra, Quinn, Stuckey, Tiao, and Udall—to work in its three sales zones—Zone 1, Zone 2, and Zone 3. Each sales representative works in exactly one of the sales zones, in accordance with the following conditions: Either Parra or Tiao (but not both) works in Zone 1. Either Tiao or Udall (but not both) works in Zone 2. Parra and Quinn work in the same sales zone as each other. Stuckey and Udall work in the same sales zone as each other. There are more of the sales representatives working in Zone 3 than in Zone 2.
question: Which one of the following could be an accurate matching of the sales representatives to the sales zones in which they work?
options: A) Zone 1: Kim, Parra Zone 2: Stuckey, Udall Zone 3: Mahr, Quinn, Tiao
B) Zone 1: Kim, Tiao Zone 2: Stuckey, Udall Zone 3: Mahr, Parra, Quinn
C) Zone 1: Parra, Quinn Zone 2: Kim, Udall Zone 3: Mahr, Stuckey, Tiao
D) Zone 1: Stuckey, Udall Zone 2: Kim, Tiao Zone 3: Mahr, Parra, Quinn
E) Zone 1: Tiao Zone 2: Kim, Parra, Quinn Zone 3: Stuckey, Udall
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
sales_reps = EnumSort([Kim, Mahr, Parra, Quinn, Stuckey, Tiao, Udall])
zones = EnumSort([Zone_1, Zone_2, Zone_3])
works_in = Function([sales_reps, zones] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([r:sales_reps], And(works_in(r, Zone_1), Not(works_in(Parra, Zone_1)))) ::: Either Parra or Tiao (but not both) works in Zone 1
ForAll([r:sales_reps], And(works_in(r, Zone_2), Not(works_in(Tiao, Zone_2)))) ::: Either Tiao or Udall (but not both) works in Zone 2
works_in(Parra, Zone_1) == works_in(Quinn, Zone_1) ::: Parra and Quinn work in the same sales zone as each other
works_in(Stuckey, Zone_3) == works_in(Udall, Zone_3) ::: Stuckey and Udall work in the same sales zone as each other
Count([z:zones], works_in(Mahr, z)) > Count([z:zones], works_in(Tiao, z)) ::: There are more of the sales representatives working in Zone 3 than in Zone 2

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following could be an accurate matching of the sales representatives to the sales zones in which they work?
is_sat(And(works_in(Kim, Zone_1), works_in(Parra, Zone_1), works_in(Stuckey, Zone_2), works_in(Udall, Zone_2), works_in(Mahr, Zone_3), works_in(Quinn, Zone_3), works_in(Tiao, Zone_3))) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(works_in(Kim, Zone_1), works_in(Tiao, Zone_1), works_in(Stuckey, Zone_2), works_in(Udall, Zone_2), works_in(Mahr, Zone_3), works_in(Parra, Zone_3), works_in(Quinn, Zone_3))) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(works_in(Parra, Zone_1), works_in(Quinn, Zone_1), works_in(Stuckey, Zone_2), works_in(Udall, Zone_2), works_in(Mahr, Zone_3), works_in(Kim, Zone_3), works_in(Tiao, Zone_3))) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(works_in(Stuckey, Zone_1), works_in(Udall, Zone_1), works_in(Kim, Zone_2), works_in(Tiao, Zone_2), works_in(Mahr, Zone_3), works_in(Parra, Zone_3), works_in(Quinn, Zone_3))) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(works_in(Tiao, Zone_1), works_in(Kim, Zone_2), works_in(Parra, Zone_2), works_in(Quinn, Zone_2), works_in(Stuckey, Zone_3), works_in(Udall, Zone_3), works_in(Mahr, Zone_3))) ::: (E)

question: If more sales representatives work in Zone 1 than in Zone 3, then which one of the following could be true?
options: A) Kim works in Zone 2.
B) Mahr works in Zone 2.
C) Parra works in Zone 3.
D) Tiao works in Zone 1.
E) Udall works in Zone 3.
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
sales_reps = EnumSort([Kim, Mahr, Parra, Quinn, Stuckey, Tiao, Udall])
zones = EnumSort([Zone_1, Zone_2, Zone_3])
works_in = Function([sales_reps, zones] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([r:sales_reps], And(works_in(r, Zone_1), works_in(r, Zone_2), works_in(r, Zone_3))) ::: each sales representative works in exactly one of the sales zones
And(works_in(Parra, Zone_1), Not(works_in(Tiao, Zone_1))) ::: Either Parra or Tiao (but not both) works in Zone 1
And(works_in(Tiao, Zone_2), Not(works_in(Udall, Zone_2))) ::: Either Tiao or Udall (but not both) works in Zone 2
works_in(Parra, Zone_1) == works_in(Quinn, Zone_1) ::: Parra and Quinn work in the same sales zone as each other
works_in(Stuckey, Zone_2) == works_in(Udall, Zone_2) ::: Stuckey and Udall work in the same sales zone as each other
Count([z:zones], works_in(Stuckey, z)) > Count([z:zones], works_in(Udall, z)) ::: there are more of the sales representatives working in Zone 3 than in Zone 2

# Options
Question ::: If more sales representatives work in Zone 1 than in Zone 3, then which one of the following could be true?
is_sat(works_in(Kim, Zone_2)) ::: (A)
is_sat(works_in(Mahr, Zone_2)) ::: (B)
is_sat(works_in(Parra, Zone_3)) ::: (C)
is_sat(works_in(Tiao, Zone_1)) ::: (D)
is_sat(works_in(Udall, Zone_3)) ::: (E)
------

context: A realtor will show a prospective buyer seven houses—J, K, L, M, N, 0, and P—during a single day. The first and second houses to be shown will be shown in the morning; the third, fourth, and fifth houses to be shown will be shown in the afternoon; the sixth and seventh houses to be shown will be shown in the evening. The houses will be shown according to the following rules: J must be shown in the evening. K cannot be shown in the morning. L must be shown at some time after K is shown and at some time before M is shown.
question: Which one of the following must be true?
options: A) K is shown in the evening.
B) L is shown in the afternoon.
C) L is shown in the evening.
D) M is shown in the morning.
E) M is shown in the afternoon.
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
houses = EnumSort([J, K, L, M, N, O, P])
shown = Function([houses] -> [int])
ForAll([h:houses], And(1 <= shown(h), shown(h) <= 7))

# Constraints
And(shown(J) == 6, shown(K)!= 1) ::: J must be shown in the evening. K cannot be shown in the morning.
And(shown(L) > shown(K), shown(M) < shown(L)) ::: L must be shown at some time after K is shown and at some time before M is shown.

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following must be true?
is_sat(shown(K) == 7) ::: (A)
is_sat(shown(L) == 3) ::: (B)
is_sat(shown(L) == 6) ::: (C)
is_sat(shown(M) == 1) ::: (D)
is_sat(shown(M) == 3) ::: (E)
------

context: Exactly five witnesses—Franco, Garcia, Hong, Iturbe, and Jackson—are to be scheduled to testify at a hearing that is to take exactly three days of one week—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Each witness testifies on exactly one day of the hearing. The schedule must meet the following conditions: Franco does not testify on the same day that Garcia testifies. Iturbe testifies on Wednesday. Exactly two witnesses testify on Tuesday. Hong does not testify on Monday. At least one witness testifies on Monday.
question: Which one of the following is an acceptable schedule of witnesses?
options: A) Monday: Franco Tuesday: Hong and Iturbe Wednesday: Garcia and Jackson
B) Monday: Franco and Hong Tuesday: Iturbe and Jackson Wednesday: Garcia
C) Monday: Garcia Tuesday: Franco and Iturbe Wednesday: Hong and Jackson
D) Monday: Garcia and Jackson Tuesday: Franco and Hong Wednesday: Iturbe
E) Monday: Garcia and Jackson Tuesday: Hong Wednesday: Franco and Iturbe
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
witnesses = EnumSort([Franco, Garcia, Hong, Iturbe, Jackson])
testifies = Function([witnesses, days] -> [bool])
days = EnumSort([Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday])

# Constraints
ForAll([w:witnesses], Count([d:days], testifies(w, d)) == 1) ::: each witness testifies on exactly one day of the hearing
And(testifies(Franco, Monday), Not(testifies(Garcia, Monday))) ::: Franco does not testify on the same day that Garcia testifies
testifies(Iturbe, Wednesday) ::: Iturbe testifies on Wednesday
Count([d:days], testifies(w, d)) == 2 ::: exactly two witnesses testify on Tuesday
Not(testifies(Hong, Monday)) ::: Hong does not testify on Monday
Count([w:witnesses], testifies(w, Monday)) >= 1 ::: at least one witness testifies on Monday

# Options
Question ::: ::: Which one of the following is an acceptable schedule of witnesses?
is_sat(And(testifies(Franco, Monday), testifies(Hong, Tuesday), testifies(Iturbe, Wednesday), testifies(Garcia, Tuesday), testifies(Jackson, Wednesday))) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(testifies(Franco, Monday), testifies(Hong, Tuesday), testifies(Iturbe, Wednesday), testifies(Garcia, Wednesday), testifies(Jackson, Tuesday))) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(testifies(Garcia, Monday), testifies(Franco, Tuesday), testifies(Iturbe, Wednesday), testifies(Hong, Tuesday), testifies(Jackson, Wednesday))) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(testifies(Garcia, Monday), testifies(Franco, Tuesday), testifies(Iturbe, Wednesday), testifies(Hong, Wednesday), testifies(Jackson, Tuesday))) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(testifies(Garcia, Monday), testifies(Franco, Tuesday), testifies(Iturbe, Wednesday), testifies(Hong, Tuesday), testifies(Jackson, Wednesday))) ::: (E)
------

context: A maintenance company that takes service requests from three clients—Image, Solide, and Truvest—plans to set targets for its average service response times. Service targets will be set at 3 days, 2 days, or 1 day. Two service targets are set for each client—one for requests received through the maintenance company's website and one for requests received by voicemail. The six targets are set according to the following conditions: None of the clients can have a website target that is longer than its voicemail target. Image's voicemail target must be shorter than the other clients' voicemail targets. Solide's website target must be shorter than Truvest's website target.
question: If Solide's voicemail target is shorter than Truvest's website target, which one of the following targets could be 2 days?
options: A) Image's website target
B) Image's voicemail target
C) Solide's website target
D) Truvest's voicemail target
E) Truvest's website target
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
clients = EnumSort([Image, Solide, Truvest])
targets = EnumSort([website, voicemail])
targets_values = EnumSort([1, 2, 3])
targets_values_set = Function([clients, targets] -> [targets_values])

# Constraints
ForAll([c:clients], ForAll([t:targets], targets_values_set(c, t)!= targets_values_set(c, t))) ::: None of the clients can have a website target that is longer than its voicemail target
ForAll([c:clients], targets_values_set(Image, voicemail) < targets_values_set(c, voicemail)) ::: Image's voicemail target must be shorter than the other clients' voicemail targets
ForAll([c:clients], targets_values_set(Solide, website) < targets_values_set(Truvest, website)) ::: Solide's website target must be shorter than Truvest's website target

# Options
Question ::: If Solide's voicemail target is shorter than Truvest's website target, which one of the following targets could be 2 days?
is_valid(targets_values_set(Solide, voicemail) == 2) ::: (A)
is_valid(targets_values_set(Image, website) == 2) ::: (B)
is_valid(targets_values_set(Solide, website) == 2) ::: (C)
is_valid(targets_values_set(Truvest, voicemail) == 2) ::: (D)
is_valid(targets_values_set(Truvest, website) == 2) ::: (E)
------

context: An editor will edit seven articles, one at a time. Three of the articles—G, H, and J—cover finance; three other articles—Q, R, and S—cover nutrition; and the remaining article, Y, covers wildlife. The order in which the articles are edited is subject to the following conditions: Consecutive articles cannot cover the same topic as each other. S can be earlier than Q only if Q is third. S must be earlier than Y. J must be earlier than G, and G must be earlier than R.
question: Which one of the following is an acceptable order for editing the articles, from first through seventh?
options: A) H, S, J, Q, Y, G, R
B) J, Q, G, H, S, Y, R
C) Q, J, S, H, Y, G, R
D) Q, J, Y, S, G, R, H
E) S, G, Q, J, Y, R, H
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
articles = EnumSort([G, H, J, Q, R, S, Y])
edited = Function([articles] -> [int])
ForAll([a:articles], And(1 <= edited(a), edited(a) <= 7))

# Constraints
Distinct([a:articles], edited(a)) ::: consecutive articles cannot cover the same topic as each other
And(edited(Q) == 3, edited(S) < edited(Q)) ::: S can be earlier than Q only if Q is third
edited(S) < edited(Y) ::: S must be earlier than Y
edited(J) < edited(G) ::: J must be earlier than G
edited(G) < edited(R) ::: G must be earlier than R

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following is an acceptable order for editing the articles, from first through seventh?
is_sat(And(edited(H) == 1, edited(S) == 2, edited(J) == 3, edited(Q) == 4, edited(Y) == 5, edited(G) == 6, edited(R) == 7)) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(edited(J) == 1, edited(Q) == 2, edited(G) == 3, edited(H) == 4, edited(S) == 5, edited(Y) == 6, edited(R) == 7)) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(edited(Q) == 1, edited(J) == 2, edited(S) == 3, edited(H) == 4, edited(Y) == 5, edited(G) == 6, edited(R) == 7)) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(edited(Q) == 1, edited(J) == 2, edited(Y) == 3, edited(S) == 4, edited(G) == 5, edited(R) == 6, edited(H) == 7)) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(edited(S) == 1, edited(G) == 2, edited(Q) == 3, edited(J) == 4, edited(Y) == 5, edited(R) == 6, edited(H) == 7)) ::: (E)
------

question: Which one of the following CANNOT be true?

# Constraints
ForAll([t:topics], And(gives(Farley, t), gives(Garcia, t), gives(Holden, t), gives(Jiang, t))) ::: each art historian gives a lecture on a different one of the topics

context: Three rugs will be woven out of colored thread. Six colors of thread are available—forest, olive, peach, turquoise, white, and yellow—exactly five of which will be used to weave the rugs. Each color that is used will be used in only one of the rugs. The rugs are either solid—woven in a single color—or multicolored. The rugs must be woven according to the following rules: In any rug in which white is used, two other colors are also used. In any rug in which olive is used, peach is also used. Forest and turquoise are not used together in a rug. Peach and turquoise are not used together in a rug. Peach and yellow are not used together in a rug.
question: Which one of the following could be the colors of the three rugs?
options: A) forest only; turquoise only; olive, peach, and white
B) forest only; turquoise only; olive, peach, and yellow
C) peach only; turquoise only; forest, olive, and white
D) yellow only; forest and turquoise; olive and peach
E) yellow only; olive and peach; turquoise and white
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
colors = EnumSort([forest, olive, peach, turquoise, white, yellow])
used = Function([colors] -> [bool])
ForAll([c:colors], And(used(c), Not(used(c)))) ::: each color that is used will be used in only one of the rugs

# Constraints
ForAll([c:colors], Implies(used(c), Count([c2:colors], And(used(c2), c2!= c)) >= 2)) ::: In any rug in which white is used, two other colors are also used
ForAll([c:colors], Implies(used(c), And(used(olive), used(peach)))) ::: In any rug in which olive is used, peach is also used
ForAll([c:colors], Implies(used(forest), used(turquoise))) ::: Forest and turquoise are not used together in a rug
ForAll([c:colors], Implies(used(peach), used(turquoise))) ::: Peach and turquoise are not used together in a rug
ForAll([c:colors], Implies(used(peach), used(yellow))) ::: Peach and yellow are not used together in a rug

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following could be the colors of the three rugs?
is_sat(And(used(forest), used(turquoise), used(olive), used(peach), used(white))) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(used(forest), used(turquoise), used(olive), used(peach), used(yellow))) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(used(peach), used(turquoise), used(forest), used(olive), used(white))) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(used(yellow), used(forest), used(turquoise), used(olive), used(peach))) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(used(yellow), used(olive), used(peach), used(turquoise), used(white))) ::: (E)

context: The manager of a photography business must assign at least two photographers to each of two graduation ceremonies—one at Silva University and the other at Thorne University. The following constraints apply: Frost must be assigned together with Heideck to one of the graduation ceremonies. If Lai and Mays are both assigned, it must be to different ceremonies. If Gonzalez is assigned to the Silva University ceremony, then Lai must be assigned to the Thorne University ceremony. If Knutson is not assigned to the Thorne University ceremony, then both Heideck and Mays must be assigned to it.
question: Which one of the following is an acceptable assignment of photographers to the two graduation ceremonies?
options: A) Silva University: Gonzalez, Lai Thorne University: Frost, Heideck, Mays
B) Silva University: Gonzalez, Mays Thorne University: Knutson, Lai
C) Silva University: Frost, Gonzalez, Heideck Thorne University: Knutson, Lai, Mays

E) Silva University: Frost, Heideck, Mays Thorne University: Gonzalez, Knutson, Lai
raw_logic_programs:

ceremonies = EnumSort([Silva_University, Thorne_University])
photographers = EnumSort([Frost, Gonzalez, Heideck, Knutson, Lai, Mays])
assigns = Function([ceremonies, photographers] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([c:ceremonies], Count([p:photographers], assigns(c, p)) >= 2) ::: at least two photographers are assigned to each of two graduation ceremonies
And(assigns(Silva_University, Frost), assigns(Silva_University, Heideck)) ::: Frost must be assigned together with Heideck to one of the graduation ceremonies
And(assigns(Thorne_University, Lai), assigns(Thorne_University, Mays)) ::: If Lai and Mays are both assigned, it must be to different ceremonies
And(assigns(Silva_University, Gonzalez), assigns(Thorne_University, Lai)) ::: If Gonzalez is assigned to the Silva University ceremony, then Lai must be assigned to the Thorne University ceremony
And(Not(assigns(Thorne_University, Knutson)), assigns(Thorne_University, Heideck), assigns(Thorne_University, Mays)) ::: If Knutson is not assigned to the Thorne University ceremony, then both Heideck and Mays must be assigned to it

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following is an acceptable assignment of photographers to the two graduation ceremonies?
is_sat(And(assigns(Silva_University, Gonzalez), assigns(Thorne_University, Lai))) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(assigns(Silva_University, Gonzalez), assigns(Thorne_University, Mays))) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(assigns(Silva_University, Frost), assigns(Silva_University, Gonzalez), assigns(Silva_University, Heideck))) ::: (C)

is_sat(And(assigns(Silva_University, Frost), assigns(Silva_University, Heideck), assigns(Silva_University, Mays))) ::: (E)

options: A) Lifestyle: both photographs by Fuentes Metro: one photograph by Fuentes and one by Hue Sports: one photograph by Gagnon and one by Hue

raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
photographers = EnumSort([Fuentes, Gagnon, Hue])
sections = EnumSort([Lifestyle, Metro, Sports])

ForAll([p:photographers], And(Count([s:sections], photos(p, s)) >= 1, Count([s:sections], photos(p, s)) <= 3)) ::: For each photographer, at least one but no more than three of that photographers photographs must appear
And(photos(Fuentes, Lifestyle), photos(Fuentes, Metro)) ::: At least one photograph in the Lifestyle section must be by a photographer who has at least one photograph in the Metro section
Count([s:sections], photos(Hue, s)) == Count([s:sections], photos(Fuentes, s)) ::: The number of Hue's photographs in the Lifestyle section must be the same as the number of Fuentes photographs in the Sports section

Each of the available photographs was taken by one of three photographers: Fuentes, Gagnon, and Hue. Selection of the photographs is constrained by the following conditions: For each photographer, at least one but no more than three of that photographers photographs must appear. At least one photograph in the Lifestyle section must be by a photographer who has at least one photograph in the Metro section. The number of Hue's photographs in the Lifestyle section must be the same as the number of Fuentes photographs in the Sports section. None of Gagnon's photographs can be in the Sports section.
question: If one photograph in the Metro section is by Fuentes and one is by Hue, then which one of the following could be true?
options: A) Both photographs in the Lifestyle section are by Fuentes.
B) Both photographs in the Lifestyle section are by Gagnon.
C) One photograph in the Lifestyle section is by Gagnon and one is by Hue.
D) Both photographs in the Lifestyle section are by Hue.
E) Both photographs in the Sports section are by Fuentes.
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
photographers = EnumSort([Fuentes, Gagnon, Hue])
sections = EnumSort([Lifestyle, Metro, Sports])
photos = Function([photographers, sections] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([p:photographers], Count([s:sections], photos(p, s)) >= 1) ::: For each photographer, at least one but no more than three of that photographers photographs must appear
And(photos(Fuentes, Lifestyle), photos(Fuentes, Metro)) ::: At least one photograph in the Lifestyle section must be by a photographer who has at least one photograph in the Metro section
Count([s:sections], photos(Hue, s)) == Count([s:sections], photos(Fuentes, s)) ::: The number of Hue's photographs in the Lifestyle section must be the same as the number of Fuentes photographs in the Sports section
ForAll([s:sections], Not(photos(Gagnon, s))) ::: None of Gagnon's photographs can be in the Sports section

# Options
Question ::: If one photograph in the Metro section is by Fuentes and one is by Hue, then which one of the following could be true?
is_sat(And(photos(Fuentes, Lifestyle), photos(Fuentes, Lifestyle))) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(photos(Gagnon, Lifestyle), photos(Hue, Lifestyle))) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(photos(Gagnon, Lifestyle), photos(Hue, Lifestyle))) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(photos(Hue, Lifestyle), photos(Hue, Lifestyle))) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(photos(Fuentes, Sports), photos(Fuentes, Sports))) ::: (E)
------

context: A publisher is planning to publish six cookbooks—K, L, M, N, O, and P—over the course of the next year. K and N must be published in the same season as each other. If K is published in the fall, O must also be published in the fall. If M is published in the fall, N must be published in the spring
question: If M is published in the fall, which one of the following is a pair of cookbooks that could both be published in the fall along with M?

B) L and N
C) L and 0
D) N and P
E) 0 and P
raw_logic_programs:

And(published(K, fall), published(N, fall)) ::: K and N must be published in the same season as each other

context: During the weeklong grand opening of a new antique shop, the antique dealer will auction exactly one antique per day for six consecutive days—June 1st through June 6th. The antiques to be auctioned are: a harmonica, a lamp, a mirror, a sundial, a table, and a vase. The following conditions apply: The sundial is not auctioned on June 1st. If the harmonica is auctioned on an earlier date than the lamp, then the mirror is also auctioned on an earlier date than the lamp. The sundial is auctioned on an earlier date than the mirror and also on an earlier date than the vase. The table is auctioned on an earlier date than the harmonica or on an earlier date than the vase, but not both.
question: Which one of the following could be an accurate list of the six antiques, in the order in which they are auctioned, from June 1st through June 6th?
options: A) harmonica, table, sundial, lamp, vase, mirror
B) lamp, harmonica, sundial, mirror, vase, table
C) harmonica, sundial, table, mirror, lamp, vase
D) sundial, mirror, harmonica, table, vase, lamp
E) vase, sundial, lamp, harmonica, table, mirror
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
antiques = EnumSort([harmonica, lamp, mirror, sundial, table, vase])
auctioned = Function([antiques, days] -> [bool])
days = EnumSort([June_1st, June_2nd, June_3rd, June_4th, June_5th, June_6th])

# Constraints
ForAll([a:antiques], Not(auctioned(a, June_1st))) ::: The sundial is not auctioned on June 1st
And(auctioned(harmonica, June_1st), auctioned(lamp, June_1st), auctioned(mirror, June_1st)) ::: If the harmonica is auctioned on an earlier date than the lamp, then the mirror is also auctioned on an earlier date than the lamp
And(auctioned(sundial, June_1st), auctioned(mirror, June_1st), auctioned(vase, June_1st)) ::: The sundial is auctioned on an earlier date than the mirror and also on an earlier date than the vase
And(auctioned(table, June_1st), auctioned(harmonica, June_1st), Not(auctioned(vase, June_1st))) ::: The table is auctioned on an earlier date than the harmonica or on an earlier date than the vase, but not both

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following could be an accurate list of the six antiques, in the order in which they are auctioned, from June 1st through June 6th?
is_sat(And(auctioned(harmonica, June_1st), auctioned(table, June_1st), auctioned(sundial, June_1st), auctioned(lamp, June_1st), auctioned(vase, June_1st), auctioned(mirror, June_1st))) ::: (A)
is_sat(And(auctioned(lamp, June_1st), auctioned(harmonica, June_1st), auctioned(sundial, June_1st), auctioned(mirror, June_1st), auctioned(vase, June_1st), auctioned(table, June_1st))) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(auctioned(harmonica, June_1st), auctioned(sundial, June_1st), auctioned(table, June_1st), auctioned(mirror, June_1st), auctioned(lamp, June_1st), auctioned(vase, June_1st))) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(auctioned(sundial, June_1st), auctioned(mirror, June_1st), auctioned(harmonica, June_1st), auctioned(table, June_1st), auctioned(vase, June_1st), auctioned(lamp, June_1st))) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(auctioned(vase, June_1st), auctioned(sundial, June_1st), auctioned(lamp, June_1st), auctioned(harmonica, June_1st), auctioned(table, June_1st), auctioned(mirror, June_1st))) ::: (E)

Zinn's audition must take place earlier than Yoshida's audition.
question: Which one of the following could be the order of the auditions, from first to last?
options: A) Kammer, Trillo, Zinn, Waite, Lugo, Yoshida
B) Waite, Kammer, Yoshida, Zinn, Lugo, Trillo

ForAll([s:singers], And(recorded(s, 5), Not(recorded(s, 6)))) ::: Zinn's audition must take place earlier than Yoshida's audition.

# Options

is_valid(And(recorded(Waite, 1), recorded(Kammer, 2), recorded(Yoshida, 3), recorded(Zinn, 4), recorded(Lugo, 5), recorded(Trillo, 6))) ::: (B)

context: A teacher will assign each of five students—Juana, Kelly, Lateefah, Mei, and Olga—to exactly one of two research teams, the green team and the red team. One team will have two members, and the other will have three members. One member of each team will be designated as facilitator. The assignment must satisfy the following conditions: Juana is assigned to a different team than Olga is. Lateefah is assigned to the green team. Kelly is not a facilitator. Olga is a facilitator.
question: Which one of the following must be false?
options: A) Lateefah is a facilitator, and she is assigned to the same team as Kelly is.
B) Mei is a facilitator, and she is assigned to the same team as Kelly is.
C) Olga is a facilitator, and she is assigned to the same team as Mei is.
D) Lateefah is a facilitator, and she is assigned to a different team than Juana is.
E) Mei is a facilitator, and she is assigned to a different team than Olga is.
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
students = EnumSort([Juana, Kelly, Lateefah, Mei, Olga])
teams = EnumSort([green, red])
assignments = Function([students, teams] -> [bool])
facilitators = Function([students, teams] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([s:students], And(Count([t:teams], assignments(s, t)) == 1, Count([t:teams], assignments(s, t)) == 1)) ::: one team will have two members, and the other will have three members
ForAll([s:students], And(Not(assignments(s, green)), Not(assignments(s, red)))) ::: one member of each team will be designated as facilitator

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following must be false?
is_false(And(facilitators(Lateefah, green), assignments(Lateefah, green) == assignments(Kelly, green))) ::: (A)
is_false(And(facilitators(Mei, green), assignments(Mei, green) == assignments(Kelly, green))) ::: (B)
is_false(And(facilitators(Olga, green), assignments(Olga, green) == assignments(Mei, green))) ::: (C)
is_false(And(facilitators(Lateefah, green), assignments(Lateefah, green)!= assignments(Juana, green))) ::: (D)
is_false(And(facilitators(Mei, green), assignments(Mei, green)!= assignments(Olga, green))) ::: (E)
------

context: An author is planning to write a mystery novel consisting of seven chapters, chapter 1 through chapter 7. Each of seven different clues—R, S, T, U, W, X, and Z—is to be mentioned exactly once, one clue per chapter. The order in which the clues are mentioned is subject to the following constraints: T cannot be mentioned in chapter 1. T must be mentioned before W, and there must be exactly two chapters separating the mention of T from the mention of W. S and Z cannot be mentioned in adjacent chapters. W and X cannot be mentioned in adjacent chapters. U and X must be mentioned in adjacent chapters.
question: Which one of the following could be the order in which the clues are mentioned, from the first chapter through the seventh?
options: A) S, T, Z, X, U, W, R
B) T, X, U, W, S, R, Z
C) U, S, X, T, Z, R, W
D) X, U, T, Z, R, W, S
E) Z, R, T, U, X, W, S
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
clues = EnumSort([R, S, T, U, W, X, Z])
mentioned = Function([clues, int] -> [bool])
ForAll([c:clues], And(1 <= mentioned(c, 1), mentioned(c, 7)))

# Constraints
ForAll([c:clues], Not(mentioned(c, 1))) ::: T cannot be mentioned in chapter 1
ForAll([c:clues], Not(mentioned(c, 2))) ::: T must be mentioned before W, and there must be exactly two chapters separating the mention of T from the mention of W
ForAll([c:clues], Not(mentioned(c, 3))) ::: S and Z cannot be mentioned in adjacent chapters
ForAll([c:clues], Not(mentioned(c, 4))) ::: W and X cannot be mentioned in adjacent chapters
ForAll([c:clues], And(mentioned(U, 5), mentioned(X, 6))) ::: U and X must be mentioned in adjacent chapters

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following could be the order in which the clues are mentioned, from the first chapter through the seventh?

context: Exactly eight books—F, G, H, I, K, L, M, O—are placed on a bookcase with exactly three shelves—the top shelf, the middle shelf, and the bottom shelf. At least two books are placed on each shelf. The following conditions must apply: More of the books are placed on the bottom shelf than the top shelf. I is placed on the middle shelf. K is placed on a higher shelf than F. O is placed on a higher shelf than L. F is placed on the same shelf as M.
question: Which one of the following could be a complete and accurate list of the books placed on the bottom shelf?
options: A) F, M
B) F, H, M
C) G, H, K
D) F, G, M, O
E) G, H, L, M
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
books = EnumSort([F, G, H, I, K, L, M, O])
shelves = EnumSort([top, middle, bottom])
placed = Function([books, shelves] -> [bool])
ForAll([b:books], And(placed(b, top), placed(b, middle), placed(b, bottom)))
ForAll([b:books], And(placed(b, top), Not(placed(b, middle))))
ForAll([b:books], And(placed(b, middle), Not(placed(b, top))))
ForAll([b:books], And(placed(b, bottom), Not(placed(b, top))))
ForAll([b:books], And(placed(b, bottom), Not(placed(b, middle))))

# Constraints
Count([b:books], placed(b, bottom)) > Count([b:books], placed(b, top)) ::: More of the books are placed on the bottom shelf than the top shelf
placed(I, middle) ::: I is placed on the middle shelf
placed(K, top) -> placed(F, top) ::: K is placed on a higher shelf than F
placed(O, top) -> placed(L, top) ::: O is placed on a higher shelf than L
placed(F, bottom) -> placed(M, bottom) ::: F is placed on the same shelf as M

# Options
Question ::: Which one of the following could be a complete and accurate list of the books placed on the bottom shelf?
is_sat(placed(F, bottom) == placed(M, bottom)) ::: (A)

Iturbe testifies on Wednesday. Exactly two witnesses testify on Tuesday. Hong does not testify on Monday. At least one witness testifies on Monday.
question: Which one of the following CANNOT be true of the schedule?
options: A) Franco is the only witness scheduled to testify on Monday.
B) Franco is scheduled to testify on the same day as Iturbe.
C) Garcia and Hong are both scheduled to testify on Tuesday.
D) Garcia is the only witness scheduled to testify on Monday and Hong is one of two witnesses scheduled to testify on Wednesday.
E) Jackson is scheduled to testify on Tuesday and two witnesses are scheduled to testify on Monday.

witnesses = EnumSort([Franco, Garcia, Hong, Iturbe, Jackson])
testifies = Function([witnesses, days] -> [bool])
days = EnumSort([Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday])

ForAll([w:witnesses], Count([d:days], testifies(w, d)) == 1) ::: each witness testifies on exactly one day of the hearing
And(testifies(Franco, Monday), Not(testifies(Garcia, Monday))) ::: Franco does not testify on the same day that Garcia testifies
testifies(Iturbe, Wednesday) ::: Iturbe testifies on Wednesday

Count([w:witnesses], testifies(w, Monday)) >= 1 ::: at least one witness testifies on Monday

is_sat(And(testifies(Franco, d), testifies(Iturbe, d) forall d in days)) ::: (B)
is_sat(And(testifies(Garcia, Tuesday), testifies(Hong, Tuesday))) ::: (C)
is_sat(And(testifies(Garcia, Monday), testifies(Hong, Wednesday))) ::: (D)
is_sat(And(testifies(Jackson, Tuesday), Count([w:witnesses], testifies(w, Monday)) == 2)) ::: (E)

C) The buildings owned by Southco are the King Building, the Meyer Building, and the Ortiz Building.
D) The buildings owned by Trustcorp are the Flores Tower and the Yates House.
E) The buildings owned by Trustcorp are the Garza Tower and the Lynch Building.
raw_logic_programs:
# Declarations
companies = EnumSort([RealProp, Southco, Trustcorp])
buildings = EnumSort([Garza_Tower, Yates_House, Zimmer_House, Flores_Tower, Lynch_Building, King_Building, Meyer_Building, Ortiz_Building])
owns = Function([companies, buildings] -> [bool])
classes = EnumSort([class_1, class_2, class_3])
class_of = Function([buildings] -> [classes])
trades = Function([companies, buildings] -> [bool])

# Constraints
ForAll([b:buildings], And(class_of(b) == class_1, owns(RealProp, b))) ::: RealProp owns the Garza Tower (class 1), the Yates House (class 3), and the Zimmer House (class 3)
ForAll([b:buildings], And(class_of(b) == class_3, owns(RealProp, b))) ::: RealProp owns the Garza Tower (class 1), the Yates House (class 3), and the Zimmer House (class 3)
ForAll([b:buildings], And(class_of(b) == class_2, owns(Southco, b))) ::: Southco owns the Flores Tower (class 1) and the Lynch Building (class 2)
ForAll([b:buildings], And(class_of(b) == class_1, owns(Southco, b))) ::: Southco owns the Flores Tower (class 1) and the Lynch Building (class 2)
ForAll([b:buildings], And(class_of(b) == class_2, owns(Trustcorp, b))) ::: Trustcorp owns the King Building, the Meyer Building, and the Ortiz Building, all of which are class 2
ForAll([b:buildings], And(class_of(b) == class_3, owns(Trustcorp, b))) ::: Trustcorp owns the King Building, the Meyer Building, and the Ortiz Building, all of which
